Edmund M. Spieker, of this
year's graduating class, tendered
his resignation as editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER at the regular
meeting of the staff on Monday,
and Reuben Oppenheimer, of the
Class of '18, was elected to take his
place. Mr. Spieker succeeded John
Saulsbury Short, '15, as head of
the paper in January, 1915, and has
held the position since that time.
It was his intention to give up the
chair earlier in the year, but circumstances prevented the acceptance of
his resignation until Monday, and
at the meeting on that day, Mr.
Oppenheimer was unanimously
chosen from the staff as his successor.
The new editor-in-chief is a
member of the sophomore class. He
has been a member of the editorial
staff since the latter part of his
freshman year, and during that
time, in addition to his regular
duties, has served as assistant to the
editor-in-chief, managing the publication of several issues of the paper.
He has been one of the most prominent editors of the paper, and has
for some time been considered ealinently qualified to take charge of
the affairs of the paper during the
remainder of this season and during next year. He has been prominent in debating and public speaking circles, having won the Tocquevill medal for 1916.
Although his election comes at a
time at which there remain but few
more issues of TILE NEWS-LETTER
to be published by the board of
1916, his experience as assistant to
Mr. Spieker will undoubtedly enable him to step into the work in
the fall without further guidance by
older members of the board. He
has had ample opportunity to familiarize himself with the details
whose acquisition is necessary to
the making of a successful editor-inchief.
At Monday's meeting, J. C.
Knipp, '17, an,d C. Prevost Boyce,
'17, were nominated for the office
of business manager, and the board
accepted the resignation of H. W.
Woodward, '16, and G. F. Ludington, '16, who requested the privilege of retiring from active service,
in order to devote their entire time
to the details pertaining to their approaching graduation in June. The
board then adjourned to meet Monday, May 15, at which time the •
business manager for 1916-17 will
be chosen from the two candidates
nominated on May 8.

By COACH J. REANEY WOLFE

Although we lost the championship to Lehigh, the 1916 Hopkins
lacrosse team is one of which the
coaches and the University have a
right to feel proud. The writer has
watched Johns Hopkins lacrosse
for about ten years, and will go on
record as saying that he has never
seen a team that, in spirit and willingness to give all they had, in
speed and stickwork and in ability
to swallow a keen disappointment
and come back fighting, surpassed
the 1916 team.
We won easily and decisively six
out of seven games. We piled up
the largest number of goals during
the season in the writer's experience—a total of 68 in 7 games (an
. average of almost io goals per
game)—and held our opponents to
a total of 20 goals.
After a two-weeks' rest we will
play the Crescents of New York, a
harder task than beating Lehigh or
Toronto, and the team is working
hard to carry off this last game.
But, after all, we do not play
solely for the pleasure and glory of
winning. The real value of college
athletics lies in the training a man
receives to bring his physical and
muscular ability under the control
of his will. If a man learns how
, to sink his individual desires for
the good of a college athletic team
and learns how to take defeat and
disappointment like a man, his college course has repaid him even in
that training alone.
The lacrosse team this year was
made up of men who were willing
and did swing together in that spirit
—there were no stars—just a good,
well-rounded team that worked
hard, and lost to a team that had
the shade of advantage that we had
last year over them. Very probably, we would have lost to Lehigh last year on their field, and
just as likely we would have won
this year on our field. Who can
tell?
One thing we can say, however,
win or lose, our men gave their best,
and that best was a spirit of work
and fight, of which the University
may well be proud.
James Lamar McCann, a student
at the University of Alabama, was
awarded a bronze medal from the
Carnegie Hero Fund Commission
and $2,000 to be used for a higher
education for saving Miss Mary T.
Munter and attempting to save Rex
Partin from drowning in the Warrior River.

TRIANGULAR DEBATING AGREEMENT MAY BE SIGNED THIS YEAR

Owing to the delay encountered
this season in getting the triangular
debate between Hopkins and the
Universities of North Carolina and
Virginia under way, the Debating
Council is seriously considering the
advisability of having the agreement between the three institutions
signed before the end of the present
collegiate year. Such a step, it is
thought, would preclude the possibility of any delay in the course of
next year's debate.
At the present time, the Debating
Council has no other debates than
those provided for by the triangular arrangement under consideration. This arrangement has proved
so satisfactory during the four years
in which it has been in existence
that it is beginning to be looked
upon as a permanent Hopkins institution.

be an officer of the Association is
not only the award of the past
achievements which the selection
conveys, but the trust in the fulfillment of future responsibility
which that selection signifies.
Between the Athletic Association and the students there should
exist the closest harmony. The Association is, of course, a representative body, and it is inevitable that
a large part of its doings should
never be submitted to the critical
survey of the McCoy Hall basement. Yet, for that very reason,
the harmony should be all the closer,
in order that the student body may
feel that the decisions of the Association are merely the crystallizations of its own sentiments. It is
when viewed in this aspect that last
Wednesday's elections become most
significant. In the men chosen that
day, the University is justified in
believing itself to be represented by
those best calculated to interpretate
its highest standards.

Straight, 'oi, for the establishment

New York, have been awarded to

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 15, 1916.

5

LIBRARY TO BE MOVED IN JUNE

CLUBS PRAISED BY REVIEWERS

LAST COTILLON BEST OF YEAR

Transfer of Books to Homewood Must
Be Completed Before Opening of
Summer School -Bids for Hauling Now Being Gathered.

Recent Washington Concert Creates Extremely Favorable Impression in the
Capital's Musical Circles—New
Constitution Adopted.

Final Dance in McCoy Hall Proves Fitting Climax for University's
Social Activities
of Year.

As a step toward moving the immense number of books from McCoy Hall to Homewood, bids have
been gotten from several companies
who desire to contract for the hauling. The trustees have appropriated $3o,000 for all moving expenses, and the cost of transferring
the library must come out of this
fund. It will require about three
weeks to put the removal into execution.
The books of the psychological
department are now being moved
to shelves in the Phipps Clinic at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital, where
they will remain permanently. The
books of the biological department
have special racks, which are now
in readiness and which will bp put
into use as soon as further arrangements can be made.
Due to the dampness of Gilman
Hall, the stacking upon which the
books are to be put has become
rusty, and many sections have had
to be sent back to the makers to be
re-enameled. These will soon be
returned, however, and the designs
for the furniture of the readingroom have already been decided
upon.
Those books needed by the summer school will be brought from
their various departments a n d
placed in the present reading-room.
All the moving must be completed
by July 5, the day of the opening
Of the summer school, as the rooms
in which many of the books are
now stacked must be used for
classes.

"The concert of the Glee and
Mandolin Club of Johns . Hopkins
University was given at the Raleigh
last evening under the patronage of
the Board of Lady Managers of the
Episcopal Eye, Ear and Throat
Hospital.
"Edmund M. Spieker, of the
Class of '16, the music genus of
the organization, was leader of the
Glee Club, and was heard as a
piano soloist and accompanist of
ability, and also as a tenor soloist,
with a very pure and sweet voice, in
incidental solos with the chorus.
"Other soloists were P. L. Lotz,
a graduate, who played with real
musicianship the violin 'Minuet' by
Beethoven and, as encore, 'Souvenir,' by Drdla. B. S. Winchester,
leader of the Mandolin Club, played
most effectively in mandolin solos,
while H. J. Gorman, guitarist, and
Edmund Spieker gave an effective
Hawaiian waltz medley.
"The clubs presented an interesting program, their 'University
Ode,' by a member of the Class
of 'g8 (De Vries), being a stamp
of their high aims."
The above is a clipping from the
Washington Times, appearing the
morning after the Musical Clubs' recent concert. Such was the success
of the affair that .plans are already
on foot to send the clubs to Washington again next year.
At a meeting held by the combined cubs last Friday (May 12) a
new constitution w a s adopted.
Among its more important features
are those which provide for practically the same kind of board that
has had charge of the clubs this
year—that is, one composed of a
president, two leaders, a treasurer
and a manager. The last office
which is to replace that of secretary, is the most important position
of the 'staff.

With Fisher and his orchestra
playing their best dance music, and
a bevy of pretty girls present, the
last of the Hopkins cotillons fol
this year, held last Saturday night
• in McCoy Hall, was a decided success. This dance marked the close
of one of the most successful years
ever experienced by the Cotillon
Board, and set up a standard that
. next year's board will have to
hustle to live up to.
Every one of the eighteen dances
was singularly enjoyable, the music
and the spring atmosphere putting
a pleasant touch to the otherwise
formal affair.
A light supper was served at
eleven, after which the dancing was
resumed. At twelve the musicians
left, and one of the most enjoyable
events of the whole college year
was brought to a close.

Realizing the necessity of a more
thorough knowledge of international problems among the University students in the future and the
present obligation for the intelligent
study of such problems brought
home by the war, a group of graduates and undergraduates met last
Friday night at the Hopkins Club,
and there, under the guidance of
Dr. John Mez, of the American Association for International Arbitration, organized a Hopkins Polity
Club.
This club, which represents a
movement already inaugurated at
the great majority of American colleges, will have for its object the
formation of small intensive study
circles of international topics. Most
of the work of the club will be accomplished by the distribution of
literature among its members and
by bringing to the University of one
or two noted lecturers a month.
Both literature and speakers will be
furnished by the American Association for International Arbitration.
The formation of the club is due
mainly to the efforts of Messrs.
Bruce Stockton Williams and Edgar T. Fell, both graduate students
in the department of political science. It was at their request that
Dr. Mez was sent down from New
York.
One of the features of the Polity
Club which will be most emphasized
by its members is its entire distinctness from any propaganda of antipreparedness and sentimental pacificism. The club does not represent
any such movement, but is rather
designed as a means of acquainting
college men with the broader point
of view from which both war and
peace are beginning to be regarded
and as a method of familiarizing
the students of the entire University with current international problems.
The club will undertake no definite organization for the remainder
of the present collegiate year, but
early next fall officers will be electHopkins.

Edmund M. Spieker, of this
year's graduating class, tendered
his resignation as editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER at the regular
meeting of the staff on Monday,
and Reuben Oppenheimer, of the
Class of '18, was elected to take his
place. Mr. Spieker succeeded John
Saulsbury Short, '15, as head of
the paper in January, 1915, and has
held the position since that time.
It was his intention to give up the
chair earlier in the year, but circumstances prevented the acceptance of
his resignation until Monday, and
at the meeting on that day, Mr.
Oppenheimer was unanimously
chosen from the staff as his successor.
The new editor-in-chief is a
member of the sophomore class. He
has been a member of the editorial
staff since the latter part of his
freshman year, and during that
time, in addition to his regular
duties, has served as assistant to the
editor-in-chief, managing the publication of several issues of the paper.
He has been one of the most prominent editors of the paper, and has
for some time been considered ealinently qualified to take charge of
the affairs of the paper during the
remainder of this season and during next year. He has been prominent in debating and public speaking circles, having won the Tocquevill medal for 1916.
Although his election comes at a
time at which there remain but few
more issues of TILE NEWS-LETTER
to be published by the board of
1916, his experience as assistant to
Mr. Spieker will undoubtedly enable him to step into the work in
the fall without further guidance by
older members of the board. He
has had ample opportunity to familiarize himself with the details
whose acquisition is necessary to
the making of a successful editor-inchief.
At Monday's meeting, J. C.
Knipp, '17, an,d C. Prevost Boyce,
'17, were nominated for the office
of business manager, and the board
accepted the resignation of H. W.
Woodward, '16, and G. F. Ludington, '16, who requested the privilege of retiring from active service,
in order to devote their entire time
to the details pertaining to their approaching graduation in June. The
board then adjourned to meet Monday, May 15, at which time the •
business manager for 1916-17 will
be chosen from the two candidates
nominated on May 8.

(Continued on page 6, col. 2)

(Continued on page 8, col. 3)

By COACH J. REANEY WOLFE

Although we lost the championship to Lehigh, the 1916 Hopkins
lacrosse team is one of which the
coaches and the University have a
right to feel proud. The writer has
watched Johns Hopkins lacrosse
for about ten years, and will go on
record as saying that he has never
seen a team that, in spirit and willingness to give all they had, in
speed and stickwork and in ability
to swallow a keen disappointment
and come back fighting, surpassed
the 1916 team.
We won easily and decisively six
out of seven games. We piled up
the largest number of goals during
the season in the writer's experience—a total of 68 in 7 games (an
. average of almost io goals per
game)—and held our opponents to
a total of 20 goals.
After a two-weeks' rest we will
play the Crescents of New York, a
harder task than beating Lehigh or
Toronto, and the team is working
hard to carry off this last game.
But, after all, we do not play
solely for the pleasure and glory of
winning. The real value of college
athletics lies in the training a man
receives to bring his physical and
muscular ability under the control
of his will. If a man learns how
, to sink his individual desires for
the good of a college athletic team
and learns how to take defeat and
disappointment like a man, his college course has repaid him even in
that training alone.
The lacrosse team this year was
made up of men who were willing
and did swing together in that spirit
—there were no stars—just a good,
well-rounded team that worked
hard, and lost to a team that had
the shade of advantage that we had
last year over them. Very probably, we would have lost to Lehigh last year on their field, and
just as likely we would have won
this year on our field. Who can
tell?
One thing we can say, however,
win or lose, our men gave their best,
and that best was a spirit of work
and fight, of which the University
may well be proud.
James Lamar McCann, a student
at the University of Alabama, was
awarded a bronze medal from the
Carnegie Hero Fund Commission
and $2,000 to be used for a higher
education for saving Miss Mary T.
Munter and attempting to save Rex
Partin from drowning in the Warrior River.

TRIANGULAR DEBATING AGREEMENT MAY BE SIGNED THIS YEAR

Owing to the delay encountered
this season in getting the triangular
debate between Hopkins and the
Universities of North Carolina and
Virginia under way, the Debating
Council is seriously considering the
advisability of having the agreement between the three institutions
signed before the end of the present
collegiate year. Such a step, it is
thought, would preclude the possibility of any delay in the course of
next year's debate.
At the present time, the Debating
Council has no other debates than
those provided for by the triangular arrangement under consideration. This arrangement has proved
so satisfactory during the four years
in which it has been in existence
that it is beginning to be looked
upon as a permanent Hopkins institution.

its highest standards.

Out of the nine justices of the
Supreme Court of the United
States, eight are college men, and
seven of these have graduated from
denominational schoo's. Of the
eighteen presidents who were college men, sixteen have come from
denominational schools.
* * *
A gift of $ro,o)o has been made
to Cornell University for the benefit of the department of Military
Science and Tactics by Willard D.
Straight, 'oi, for the establishment
of a summer camp at Ithaca. During the two weeks at camp 600 undergraduates will receive instruction similar to that given at Plattsburg.
* * *
Military scholarships for the
army training camp at Plattsburg.
New York, have been awarded to
21 'students of the Pennsylvania
State College. Financial aid will
be given by the Military Training
Association Committee, of Philadelphia. The cost to each student
will be $32.50, a third of which purchases the uniform, the remainder
paying five weeks' board. All the
Perm State students who have enrolled for the encampment have had
military experience in the cadet
regiment connected with the department of military science. The students' summer work will afford
practice in advanced training and
will enable them to fill ranks of
company and battalion commanders.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 15, 1916.

5

LIBRARY TO BE MOVED IN JUNE

CLUBS PRAISED BY REVIEWERS

LAST COTILLON BEST OF YEAR

Transfer of Books to Homewood Must
Be Completed Before Opening of
Summer School -Bids for Hauling Now Being Gathered.

Recent Washington Concert Creates Extremely Favorable Impression in the
Capital's Musical Circles—New
Constitution Adopted.

Final Dance in McCoy Hall Proves Fitting Climax for University's
Social Activities
of Year.

As a step toward moving the immense number of books from McCoy Hall to Homewood, bids have
been gotten from several companies
who desire to contract for the hauling. The trustees have appropriated $3o,000 for all moving expenses, and the cost of transferring
the library must come out of this
fund. It will require about three
weeks to put the removal into execution.
The books of the psychological
department are now being moved
to shelves in the Phipps Clinic at
the Johns Hopkins Hospital, where
they will remain permanently. The
books of the biological department
have special racks, which are now
in readiness and which will bp put
into use as soon as further arrangements can be made.
Due to the dampness of Gilman
Hall, the stacking upon which the
books are to be put has become
rusty, and many sections have had
to be sent back to the makers to be
re-enameled. These will soon be
returned, however, and the designs
for the furniture of the readingroom have already been decided
upon.
Those books needed by the summer school will be brought from
their various departments a n d
placed in the present reading-room.
All the moving must be completed
by July 5, the day of the opening
Of the summer school, as the rooms
in which many of the books are
now stacked must be used for
classes.

"The concert of the Glee and
Mandolin Club of Johns . Hopkins
University was given at the Raleigh
last evening under the patronage of
the Board of Lady Managers of the
Episcopal Eye, Ear and Throat
Hospital.
"Edmund M. Spieker, of the
Class of '16, the music genus of
the organization, was leader of the
Glee Club, and was heard as a
piano soloist and accompanist of
ability, and also as a tenor soloist,
with a very pure and sweet voice, in
incidental solos with the chorus.
"Other soloists were P. L. Lotz,
a graduate, who played with real
musicianship the violin 'Minuet' by
Beethoven and, as encore, 'Souvenir,' by Drdla. B. S. Winchester,
leader of the Mandolin Club, played
most effectively in mandolin solos,
while H. J. Gorman, guitarist, and
Edmund Spieker gave an effective
Hawaiian waltz medley.
"The clubs presented an interesting program, their 'University
Ode,' by a member of the Class
of 'g8 (De Vries), being a stamp
of their high aims."
The above is a clipping from the
Washington Times, appearing the
morning after the Musical Clubs' recent concert. Such was the success
of the affair that .plans are already
on foot to send the clubs to Washington again next year.
At a meeting held by the combined cubs last Friday (May 12) a
new constitution w a s adopted.
Among its more important features
are those which provide for practically the same kind of board that
has had charge of the clubs this
year—that is, one composed of a
president, two leaders, a treasurer
and a manager. The last office
which is to replace that of secretary, is the most important position
of the 'staff.

With Fisher and his orchestra
playing their best dance music, and
a bevy of pretty girls present, the
last of the Hopkins cotillons fol
this year, held last Saturday night
• in McCoy Hall, was a decided success. This dance marked the close
of one of the most successful years
ever experienced by the Cotillon
Board, and set up a standard that
. next year's board will have to
hustle to live up to.
Every one of the eighteen dances
was singularly enjoyable, the music
and the spring atmosphere putting
a pleasant touch to the otherwise
formal affair.
A light supper was served at
eleven, after which the dancing was
resumed. At twelve the musicians
left, and one of the most enjoyable
events of the whole college year
was brought to a close.

HOPKINS POLITY CLUB FORMED

DEFEATS SWARTHMORE TWELVE

Group of Graduates and Undergraduates
Organize for Purpose of Making Intensive Study of Modern International Problems.

(Continued from page I)

The Hopkins-Swarthmore lineup:

Realizing the necessity of a more
thorough knowledge of international problems among the University students in the future and the
present obligation for the intelligent
study of such problems brought
home by the war, a group of graduates and undergraduates met last
Friday night at the Hopkins Club,
and there, under the guidance of
Dr. John Mez, of the American Association for International Arbitration, organized a Hopkins Polity
Club.
This club, which represents a
movement already inaugurated at
the great majority of American colleges, will have for its object the
formation of small intensive study
circles of international topics. Most
of the work of the club will be accomplished by the distribution of
literature among its members and
by bringing to the University of one
or two noted lecturers a month.
Both literature and speakers will be
furnished by the American Association for International Arbitration.
The formation of the club is due
mainly to the efforts of Messrs.
Bruce Stockton Williams and Edgar T. Fell, both graduate students
in the department of political science. It was at their request that
Dr. Mez was sent down from New
York.
One of the features of the Polity
Club which will be most emphasized
by its members is its entire distinctness from any propaganda of antipreparedness and sentimental pacificism. The club does not represent
any such movement, but is rather
designed as a means of acquainting
college men with the broader point
of view from which both war and
peace are beginning to be regarded
and as a method of familiarizing
the students of the entire University with current international problems.
The club will undertake no definite organization for the remainder
of the present collegiate year, but
early next fall officers will be electHopkins.

Virginia and Rutgers, Ties Haverford, and Loses to
Pennsylvania.

The tennis team had a remarkably
successful trip last week, winning
two matches, losing one and tying
another.
The first match, played with Haverford, resulted in a tie and abounded in close play; the outcome being
in doubt all through the games.
The University of Virginia team
was next met and proved easy prey;
the final score being 5 to i in Hopkins' favor.
The next match, however, which
was played with the University of
Pennsylvania team, was the hardest
fought contest of the trip and was
finally won by Penn, 4 to 2.
The last match, which was played
with the Rutgers team, was easily
won by Hopkins; the score being
6 too.
